snippet: The trial of a bus driver accused of being too sleepy to drive when his bus crashed, killing 15 people, is among an increasing number of cases being pursued against sleepy drivers involved in crashes.
abstract: Campaign against so-called drowsy driving is moving to the courtroom, with law enforcement officials increasingly pushing to hold sleepy drivers criminally accountable when they cause fatal crashes; trial of Bronx bus driver Ophadell Williams is among the most high-profile cases to date; Williams was driving on only a few hours of sleep when he crashed tour bus, killing 15 passengers; he is charged with manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide.
lead_paragraph: The trial of a bus driver accused of being too sleepy to drive when his bus crashed, killing 15 people, is among an increasing number of cases being pursued against sleepy drivers involved in crashes.

headline.seo: Challenges in Prosecuting Drowsy Drivers Over Fatal Crashes
headline.main: Push to Prosecute Drowsy Driving May Hinge on Its Definition
headline.print_headline: Push to Prosecute Drowsy Driving May Hinge on Its Definition
